awd_titl_txt: RUI/Collaborative Research: Investigation of Ion Currents in the Oxyfuel Cutting Flame and their Links to Critical Process Parameters
awd_abstract_narration:
The award seeks to address serious persistent challenges in providing process feedback to better control and fully automate the oxyfuel cutting process.  Though it is more than a century old, oxyfuel's (or 'flame-cutting's') unparalleled performance on thick steel has rendered it an enduring favorite in shipyards, building construction, rail, defense, and countless other heavy industries.  The harsh operating environment (open flames, extreme heat) limit the ability of contemporary sensor suites to provide reliable data essential for process feedback control and automation.  A potential solution to this problem is motivated by preliminary measurements demonstrating that electrical events called 'ion currents' associated with the flame itself can reliably indicate vital process states.  The research will probe the underlying physics of the flame via modeling and experimental efforts. If successful the work could realize reliable cost-effective control and automation of the oxyfuel cutting process, a capability of great interest to many core US industries involved in construction, and major equipment manufacture for defense and energy applications. This is a collaborative research, whereby the experimental work will be undertaken at a predominantly undergraduate institute, while most of the modeling efforts will be conducted at the partner university. Engaging undergraduate students in industrially relevant research projects will hopefully encourage and promote advanced manufacturing beyond those immediately involved, and encourage broader participation. Collaboration with the partner university and the industrial partner, IHT-Automation, will also increase the workforce preparedness of both the graduate student and undergraduate students working on this project. 
 
This work tests the validity of a reduced-order ion transport model that considers standoff distance, work-surface/kerf chemical activity, and flame chemical activity with respect to the resulting current-voltage characteristic between the oxyfuel cutting torch and the workpiece.  A novel spinning disc Langmuir probe technique will establish a spatially resolved map for the ion densities in the flame.  Using these data as a reference, a multi-dimensional computational fluid dynamics simulation will be built on recently developed reduced chemical kinetic models to fully resolve the formation and transport of charged species throughout the flow.  Subsequent analysis of the modeling and experimental results will validate or reject a highly simplified one-dimensional transport model relating the current-voltage characteristic of the flame to critical events.  These include drift in standoff, ready-to-pierce, pierce success/failure, loss-of-cut prediction, drift in fuel/oxygen ratio, flameout, and potentially others.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

por.por_cntn:
This project investigated the feasibility of using the electrical properties of oxyfuel cutting torch’s preheat flame to replace sensors in the mechanized cutting process.

Part I: An Initial Empirical Approach to the Problem

A significant body of data was accumulated for the electrical properties of the oxy-methane preheat flame while controlling for fuel/oxygen ratio, total flow rate, standoff, work condition (rust, oil, salts, etc.), work temperature, and work composition.  Weak currents were monitored while applying a range of voltages between +10 and -10 volts between the torch and actively cooled metal coupons made of steel and copper.

There are three regimes: positive and negative saturation at the extremes of voltage with an ohmic regime in the center.  Regime 1 (negative saturation) and 2 (ohmic) showed highly repeatable variation with the flow rate, fuel/oxygen ratio, and standoff.

However, regime 3 was wildly unrepeatable over steel despite great care taken to control the surface condition and temperature.  However, when done over copper, experiments were extremely repeatable at the minimum currents found over steel.  It seemed that steel was contributing additional ions to the flame.

Part II: Investigating the Source of Secondary Ions

The discovery of secondary ions contributed by the work was exciting because it posed a possible means to identify ready-to-pierce, but it was also troubling since unrepeatable signals threaten the viability of a measurement.  It was important to positively identify their source.  Iron was an unlikely candidate, but carbon is already known to be essential to the primary ions in flames.

To test the hypothesis, a series of three wires with constant diameter were burned: one steel with high carbon content, one steel with low carbon content, and one 99.995% pure iron.  The test was repeated multiple times for each wire with a consistent feed rate while applying a positive voltage bias to the torch so the positive saturation current could be measured.  Then, graphite dust was fluidized and blown into the flame at various mass flow rates.

The regime 3 current was found to track with the rate of addition of carbon into the flame in all tests.

Part III: A Theoretical Framework

Over the course of the project, a pair of one-dimensional reduced-order models were constructed that provide a physics-based theoretical link between the features of the current-voltage characteristic and physical properties of the flame and cutting process.  The models showed that:

  1. Negative saturation occurs when positive ions are forced to travel back to the torch tip against the direction of flow;
  2. Positive saturation occurs when electrons are driven away from the work surface, and all remaining current is due to the surviving ions from the flame;
  3. Regime 2 appears ohmic, but is also significantly influenced by ion sheaths at the work and torch tip;
  4. Secondary ion formation simply adds to the regime 3 current unless it occurs so close to the work surface that some of the new free electrons are captured as well;

Part IV: Confirming the Flame’s Electrical Structure

A new technique for extracting spatial information from the transient insertion Langmuir (TIL) probe was developed to measure the flame’s electrical cross-section with a resolution of 0.15mm.  The results show a beautiful array of oblong ion rings approximately 1 mm across around each of the twelve preheat channels on the torch tip.  This confirmed the model’s view that ions form in the inner cones and recombine in the outer cone.

Part V: The Fitness of Measurements

Regime 2 was found to be an excellent measurement of standoff distance in a healthy cut and in preheat mode.  If the cut is allowed to cool to the point of near loss-of-cut (for example by excessive feed rate), the resistance is significantly increased by the corresponding reduction in secondary ions.  If the cut is excessively slow, top-edge dross can temporarily shorten the electrical path length, causing scatter in the measurements equivalent to the height of the dross.

Regime 1 was found to be a measurement of the flame health, since it indicates the distance over which ions needed to travel to reach the torch tip.  It is roughly equivalent to an operator adjusting the fuel/oxygen ratio by observing the length of the inner cone.

Regime 3 was found to be an indicator of ready-to-pierce, since the appearance of secondary ions is accelerated when the plate approaches its kindling temperature.


Last Modified: 11/13/2023
Modified by: Christopher R Martin

Images (1 of )
  • The standoff distance between the torch tip and the work surface versus the regime 2 electrical resistance.
    C. Martin

    Standoff versis regime 2 resistance
  • Current-voltage characteristics plotted for three combinations of standoff distance and fuel-oxygen ratio. Three regimes are visible starting from left-to-right.
    C. Martin
    Copyrighted
    Christopher R Martin
    Typical Current-Voltage Characteristics
  • The negative saturation current is the transition between regimes 1 and 2, and is shown to be well correlated with fuel/oxidizer ratio.
    C. Martin
    Copyrighted
    Christopher R Martin
    Negative Saturation Current vs F/O Ratio
  • These images show the post-processing results of horizontal slices of the oxy-methane flame taken with the transient insertion Langmuir probe.
    C. Martin
    Copyrighted
    Christopher R Martin
    Ion Current Density in the Oxy-Methane Flame
  • Regime 2 resistance was also found to vary with the cut health. At high standoffs with high feed rates, the resistance goes up when the cut "goes cold."
    C. Martin
    Copyrighted
    Christopher R Martin
    Regime 2 resistance versus cut health
  • The transient insertion Langmuir probe used to obtain the highest quality ion current density cross sections. The disc is shown with four .005in diameter wires.
    C. Martin
    Copyrighted
    Christopher R Martin
    The TIL probe

This project investigated the feasibility of using the electrical properties of oxyfuel cutting torchs preheat flame to replace sensors in the mechanized cutting process.


Part I: An Initial Empirical Approach to the Problem


A significant body of data was accumulated for the electrical properties of the oxy-methane preheat flame while controlling for fuel/oxygen ratio, total flow rate, standoff, work condition (rust, oil, salts, etc.), work temperature, and work composition. There are three regimes: positive and negative saturation at the extremes of voltage with an ohmic regime in the center. Regime 1 (negative saturation) and 2 (ohmic) showed highly repeatable variation with the flow rate, fuel/oxygen ratio, and standoff.

To test the hypothesis, a series of three wires with constant diameter were burned: one steel with high carbon content, one steel with low carbon content, and one 99.995% pure iron. The test was repeated multiple times for each wire with a consistent feed rate while applying a positive voltage bias to the torch so the positive saturation current could be measured. Negative saturation occurs when positive ions are forced to travel back to the torch tip against the direction of flow;
Positive saturation occurs when electrons are driven away from the work surface, and all remaining current is due to the surviving ions from the flame;
Regime 2 appears ohmic, but is also significantly influenced by ion sheaths at the work and torch tip;
Secondary ion formation simply adds to the regime 3 current unless it occurs so close to the work surface that some of the new free electrons are captured as well;



Part IV: Confirming the Flames Electrical Structure


A new technique for extracting spatial information from the transient insertion Langmuir (TIL) probe was developed to measure the flames electrical cross-section with a resolution of 0.15mm. Regime 2 was found to be an excellent measurement of standoff distance in a healthy cut and in preheat mode. If the cut is excessively slow, top-edge dross can temporarily shorten the electrical path length, causing scatter in the measurements equivalent to the height of the dross.


Regime 1 was found to be a measurement of the flame health, since it indicates the distance over which ions needed to travel to reach the torch tip. It is roughly equivalent to an operator adjusting the fuel/oxygen ratio by observing the length of the inner cone.


Regime 3 was found to be an indicator of ready-to-pierce, since the appearance of secondary ions is accelerated when the plate approaches its kindling temperature.					Last Modified: 11/13/2023
